text: yes, but the same error persists regardless of whether "using Plots" is there

elements.text: yes, but the same error persists regardless of whether "using Plots" is there

text:
I think before I got similar error too.

If you already did `using Plots`  then I would try `Plots.scatter` I remember when I had some trouble doing the examples I saw that `scatter` conflicted with Flux or something. EDIT: But I'm a beginner. I'm not sure what the root cause was exactly. I think scatter was found both in Flux and in Plots

text: Kim's fix is certainly correct, and in this case it seems like both Flux and GalacticOptim has "scatter", which supposedly is why there is a conflict

elements.text: Kim's fix is certainly correct, and in this case it seems like both Flux and GalacticOptim has "scatter", which supposedly is why there is a conflict

text: I didn't know that GalacticOptim also had scatter. Thank you for that information

elements.text: I didn't know that GalacticOptim also had scatter. Thank you for that information

text:
<@UC4QQPG4A> <@U69BL50BF> If it helps/saves time at all, here is what `?` gives for both `?Flux.scatter` and `?GalacticOptim.scatter` :
```scatter(op, src, idx)

Scatter operation, which applies specified operation on src according to idx and gives an new array dst. For each index k
in idx, accumulate values in dst according to

dst[:, ..., idx[k]...] = (op).(src[:, ..., k...])```

elements.text: If it helps/saves time at all, here is what

scatter(op, src, idx)

Scatter operation, which applies specified operation on src according to idx and gives an new array dst. For each index k
in idx, accumulate values in dst according to

dst[:, ..., idx[k]...] = (op).(src[:, ..., k...])
